Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program is a three-year advanced diploma in Civil Engineering Technology, followed by Years 3 and 4 to obtain a bachelor's degree in Construction Management. It provides a curriculum that combines theory, applied research, field study, and hands-on practical education. The program duration is six years in total.

Students gain knowledge and skills to manage construction projects from start to finish and master construction-related technical disciplines and soft skills. Graduates receive the academic credential designation of Hons. B.Tech (Construction Management).

The program is recognized by the construction industry and fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS). Students are eligible to obtain their Gold Seal Certification (GSC) from the Canadian Construction Association (CCA) in various roles like superintendents, foremen, estimators, project managers, owner's construction managers, and safety practitioners.

The mandatory field experience semester is offered in the spring/summer of the third year, and students need to complete a minimum of 450 hours or equivalent past field experience. They can do so through the Field Experience course or Prior Learning Assessment Recognition (PLAR) process.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program at the college prepares graduates for careers as construction managers or related roles such as project manager, project coordinator, field engineer, site superintendent, estimator, project monitor, building science specialist, building condition assessor, construction sales manager, construction claims specialist, construction quality control specialist, construction health and safety specialist, construction cost consultant, developer, project controls specialist, site inspector, contractor, or subcontractor.

Construction managers in the industry are required to have specialized skills, including knowledge of multidisciplinary teams, construction safety and quality management systems, sustainable construction practices, and a broad technical and business management background.

The program is fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB), and the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). Graduates are qualified to obtain professional memberships in various construction management associations, including the CIQS. With the completion of this degree program, graduates have completed all academic requirements for professional membership at CIQS, but must apply separately for membership and obtain the Professional Quantity Surveyors (PQS) or Construction Estimator Certified (CEC) designation.

Graduates also qualify to obtain the Gold Seal Certification (GSC) offered by other organizations.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree is offered at George Brown College and is well respected in the construction sector. The program is designed to provide education, training, and professional work experience for candidates to obtain the Gold Seal Certification offered by the Canadian Construction Association. This certification is available for superintendents, foremen, estimators, project managers, owner’s construction managers, and safety practitioners. The program is important for the construction industry as it aims to produce future graduates with necessary construction-specific skills to help strengthen the long-term success of the industry. Industry leaders like Temple Harris (vice-chairman, Gillam Group), Christopher Rick (PCL Constructors, Canada Inc.), James Zippel (general manager, Electrical Service & Projects, Ainsworth), and Greg Kozicz (president, Alberici Constructors, Ltd.) have expressed their support for the program. Michael George (president, Trisura Insurance) also emphasized the need for improved education and training in the construction sector and the importance of effective four-year degree programs like this one.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program at the college offers graduates the ability to pursue graduate studies in relevant fields. Some graduates have attended universities such as the University of Waterloo, Columbia University, and Toronto Metropolitan University for further studies.

The required courses for the Construction Management program are as follows:
- Semester 4: BLDG 2204 (Commercial Construction Technology), BLDG 2095 (Construction Estimating 1), BLDG 2114 (Construction Estimating 2 – Pricing), BLDG 3041 (Mechanical and Electrical Construction Practices), BSCI 2101 (Foundations in Building Science), and two Liberal Studies electives.
- Semester 5: BLDG 2111 (Highrise Construction Technology), BLDG 2166 (Construction Graphics 2), BLDG 3025 (Construction Estimating 3 – Bidding), BLDG 3043 (Construction Health and Safety), BLDG 3045 (Heavy Construction Management Practices 1), BLDG 3055 (Work Term Preparation 1), and one Liberal Studies elective.
- Semester 6: BLDG 1162 (Building Code Act and Regulations), BLDG 3167 (Construction Cost Control), BLDG 3168 (Capstone 1 – Bid Competition), BLDG 3169 (Work Term Preparation 2), BLDG 3175 (Heavy Construction Management Practices 2), ECON 2005 (Macro and Micro Economics), MGMT 3120 (Construction Quality Practices), and MGMT 3150 (Construction Contract Administration).
- Summer Field Experience Semester: TCOP1001 (Work Term, 450 hours).
- Semester 7: BLDG 3152 (Economics of Project Development), BLDG 3170 (Preconstruction Cost Planning), and BLDG 3177 (Application in Building Information Modelling (BIM)).

Mike Van Volsen, operations manager at Access Suspended Platforms Inc., emphasized the importance of having competent graduates enter the construction industry.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the course offerings and learning outcomes for a degree completion pathway in Construction Management at George Brown College. Here are some key facts and entities extracted from the text:

* The program includes courses with codes BLDG 3177, BLDG 3178, BLDG 4020, MGMT 4050, MGMT 4055, BLDG 4021, BLDG 4050, BLDG 4150, MGMT 4052, MGMT 4090, and MGMT 4091.
* The program consists of eight semesters, with SEMESTER 8 mentioned specifically.
* Students may be eligible to enter the degree completion pathway if they have a grade point average of 3.0 or higher from the three-year Civil Engineering Technology program (T164) at George Brown College or from a comparable program at another Ontario college.
* Courses cover topics such as Application in Building Information Modelling (BIM), Decision Analysis and Critical Thinking, Research Methods, Construction Risk Management, Sustainable Construction, Capstone 2 – Industry Research, Project Financial Monitoring, Construction Procurement 1 and 2, Leadership and Ethics for Construction Managers, and various liberal studies electives.
* The program aims to help students communicate information related to construction projects, analyze past performance to improve future projects, manage projects in a compliant, safe, ethical, and sustainable manner, use management tools to execute projects on time and within budget, recognize and value diversity, develop high-functioning teams, apply leadership strategies, analyze technical problems and develop solutions, and apply business and financial principles to manage project costs.
* Students can contact George Brown College for more information by calling 416-415-5000, ext. 6297 or emailing construction_degree@georgebrown.ca.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management offers a construction management program at George Brown College. Here are some key facts and requirements for the program:

1. Risk evaluation and mitigation strategies for construction projects are important components of the program.
2. Students will create technical documents related to the design, procurement, and execution of construction projects, managing documentation effectively.
3. Students must behave ethically and responsibly, adhering to professional codes of conduct, laws, policies, and contracts.
4. Domestic tuition for the program is $9,524.00 for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2022. International tuition is $20,465.00 for the same period. Fees are subject to change.
5. Financial assistance is available through OSAP for eligible applicants.
6. Only graduates of an Ontario College Advanced (three-year) diploma in Civil Engineering Technology are considered for admission.
7. Applicants must have a GPA of 3.0 or higher.
8. The program has been granted a seven-year term of consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities, starting May 7, 2018.
9. Students are recommended to own or purchase a laptop with Windows 10 Home 64-bit English operating system, a 9th Generation Intel Core i7-9750H processor, and at least 25 to 40 Mbps Internet speed and a ping time of 20–100 ms.
10. Laptop specifications may vary, and the above recommendations are not mandatory but strongly recommended.
